stories.headline: The NPR Politics Podcast
stories.summary: Every weekday, NPR's best political reporters are there to explain the big news coming out of Washington and the campaign trail. They don't just tell you what happened. They tell you why it matters. Every afternoon.Political wonks - get wonkier with The NPR Politics Podcast+. Your subscription supports the podcast and unlocks a sponsor-free feed. Learn more at plus.npr.org/politics

stories.headline: Venezuela leader captured. Trump says U.S. to 'run' the country. Here’s what we know
stories.summary: After months of threats, warnings and seizing of alleged drug boats – tensions between the United States and Venezuela have now come to this: the arrest of Venezuelan president Nicolás Maduro.Now, President Trump says the United States is “running the country.”In this special episode of Sources & Methods, host Mary Louise Kelly speaks with national security correspondent Greg Myre, Pentagon correspondent Tom Bowman, international correspondent Carrie Kahn and Rep. Adam Smith about the latest from Venezuela.Email the show atsourcesandmethods@npr.orgNPR+ supporters hear every episode without sponsor messages and unlock access to our complete archive. Sign up atplus.npr.org.

stories.headline: Maduro arrives in New York. What to know about the U.S. operation in Venezuela
stories.summary: Supporters of Venezuela's current and former president, Nicolas Maduro and the late Hugo Chavez, hold posters with their images in Caracas on Saturday.Jesus Vargas/Getty Imageshide caption

stories.headline: Maduro faces drug charges in U.S. even as Trump freed others convicted of trafficking

stories.headline: Zohran Mamdani sworn in as New York City mayor, capping historic rise

stories.headline: Rising from the ashes, a symbol of hope at the Rose Parade
stories.summary: Volunteers work on the top of the "Rising Together" float's centerpiece phoenix, which symbolizes the community's recovery after last year's deadly Eaton and Palisades Fires in Los Angeles. Every inch of the float must be decorated with only natural organic materials like bark, flowers and seeds.Kirk Siegler/NPRhide caption

stories.headline: The history behind the NYC subway station chosen for Mamdani's swearing-in
stories.summary: New York City's incoming mayor Zohran Mamdani picked the decommissioned subway station under City Hall as the site of his private swearing-in ceremony.Felix Lipov/Alamyhide caption

stories.headline: Subscribe to Planet Money Newsletter
stories.summary: The world is confusing. Economics can help.

stories.headline: Venezuela’s recent economic history (Update)
stories.summary: We've been checking in on the economic conditions in Venezuela for about a decade now. In response to the U.S. strike and the capture of Venezuelan president Nicolás Maduro this weekend, we're re-surfacing this episode with an update.

stories.headline: The Indicator from Planet Money
stories.summary: A bite-sized show about big ideas. From the people who makePlanet Money,The Indicatorhelps you make sense of what's happening in today's economy. It's a quick hit of insight into money, work, and business. Monday through Friday, in 10 minutes or less.

stories.headline: Venezuela’s economic descent (Updated)
stories.summary: President of Venezuela Nicolás Maduro speaking during a military ceremony commemorating on Nov. 25, 2025, in Caracas, Venezuela.Jesus Vargas/Getty Imageshide caption

stories.headline: Consider This from NPR
stories.summary: The hosts of NPR's All Things Considered help you make sense of a major news story and what it means for you, in 15 minutes. New episodes six days a week, Sunday through Friday.Support NPR and get your news sponsor-free with Consider This+. Learn more at plus.npr.org/considerthis

stories.headline: Can the global economy handle a world with fewer kids?
stories.summary: Ashley Evancho and her daughter Sophia play together at their home near Buffalo, N.Y. Evancho and her husband have decided to have only one child, a choice many people are making around the world.Lauren Petracca for NPRhide caption

stories.headline: We resolve to watch these 2026 indicators
stories.summary: Seven-foot-tall numerals for "2026" are displayed at Times Square in New York City.TIMOTHY A. CLARY / AFP via Getty Images/AFP via Getty Imageshide caption

stories.headline: Crypto soared in 2025 — and then crashed. Now what?
stories.summary: A bitcoin logo is displayed at a conference in Hong Kong on Aug. 28, 2025. Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies soared this year — until crashing in October.Vernon Yuen/AFP via Getty Imageshide caption

stories.headline: What to know about Nick Shirley, the YouTuber alleging day care fraud in Minnesota
stories.summary: YouTuber Nick Shirley films protesters demonstrating against U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement arrests in New York City in October. He went viral in late December for a video purportedly uncovering $110 million in alleged fraud by federally funded day care centers in Minnesota.Adam Gray/Getty Imageshide caption

stories.headline: Indicators of the Year, Past and Future
stories.summary: 2025 is finally over. It was a wild year for the U.S. economy. Tariffs transformed global trading, consumer sentiment hit near-historic lows, and stocks hit dramatic new heights! So … which of these economic stories defined the year?

stories.headline: Why Americans don't want to move for jobs anymore (Encore)
stories.summary: Americans are moving at record lows for work. What’s driving people to, well, not drive cross-country for jobs? On today’s episode, we explore the rising homebody economy.This episode originally aired Oct. 3, 2025.Related episodes:Why moms are leaving their paid jobsHow the end of Roe is reshaping the medical workforceFor sponsor-free episodes of The Indicator from Planet Money, subscribe to Planet Money+ via Apple Podcasts or atplus.npr.org. Fact-checking by Corey Bridges. Music byDrop Electric. Find us:TikTok,Instagram,Facebook,Newsletter.

stories.headline: Judge orders Trump administration to continue to seek funding for the CFPB
stories.summary: A view of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) headquarters building in Washington, DC, on February 10, 2025.SAUL LOEB/AFP via Getty Imageshide caption

stories.headline: Gilded Age 2.0? (Encore)
stories.summary: To hear President Trump tell it, the late 1800s, i.e. the Gilded Age, were a period of unparalleled wealth and prosperity in the U.S. But this era was also marked by corruption and wealth inequality. Sound familiar? On today's show, is history repeating itself?This episode originally aired June 5, 2025.Related:Trump's tariff role modelFor sponsor-free episodes of The Indicator from Planet Money, subscribe to Planet Money+ via Apple Podcasts or atplus.npr.org. Fact-checking bySierra Juarez. Music byDrop Electric. Find us:TikTok,Instagram,Facebook,Newsletter.

stories.headline: 2026 World Cup: North America
stories.summary: The 2026 FIFA World Cup is from June 11 to July 19, 2026. Sixteen host cities across North America, including Atlanta, Dallas, Houston, Seattle, Los Angeles, Philadelphia, San Francisco, Boston, Kansas City, Miami, and New York/New Jersey in the United States. The NPR Network will have coverage from across the country leading up to and during the championship.

stories.summary: The 2026 FIFA World Cup is from June 11 to July 19, 2026. Sixteen host cities across North America, including Atlanta, Dallas, Houston, Seattle, Los Angeles, Philadelphia, San Francisco, Boston, Kansas City, Miami, and New York/New Jersey in the United States. The NPR Network will have coverage from across the country leading up to and during the championship.

stories.headline: Memory loss: As AI gobbles up chips, prices for devices may rise
stories.summary: Idaho-based Micron Technology is one of the world's top makers of RAM chips and it has benefited from increased demand.Charlie Litchfield/APhide caption

stories.headline: Marijuana rescheduling would bring some immediate changes, but others will take time
stories.summary: Michael Stonebarger sorts young cannabis plants at a marijuana farm in Grandview, Mo., in 2022. President Trump set the process in motion to ease federal restrictions on marijuana. But his order doesn't automatically revoke laws targeting marijuana, which remains illegal to transport over state lines.Charlie Riedel/APhide caption

stories.headline: Clean energy is surging despite political attacks. But a slowdown may be looming
stories.summary: Workers install solar panels at a project this spring in Galena, Alaska.John Locher/APhide caption

stories.headline: The Rest of the Story, 2025
stories.summary: Most stories keep going even after we set down our microphones and the music fades up. That's why, at the end of each year, we look back and we take stock.

stories.headline: The secret to Nintendo's success (Encore)
stories.summary: For the next week, we're running some of our favorite shows from this year. On today's show, a brief history of Nintendo and how a small playing card company in Japan became a gaming juggernaut.This piece originally aired June 16, 2025.Related episodes:Inside video game economicsForever games: the economics of the live service modelThe boom and bust of esportsFor sponsor-free episodes of The Indicator from Planet Money, subscribe to Planet Money+ via Apple Podcasts or atplus.npr.org. Fact-checking bySierra Juarez. Music byDrop Electric. Find us:TikTok,Instagram,Facebook,Newsletter.

stories.headline: The summer I turned binge-y
stories.summary: On the eve of Netflix shoveling a fourish-hour chunk of Stranger Things onto Christmas Day, we visit the past, present, and future of binge-dropped television shows.

stories.headline: Why every A-lister also has a side hustle (Encore)
stories.summary: Happy Holidays from The Indicator! For the next week, we're running some of our favorite shows from this year. On today's show, why celebrities are increasingly investing in their own brands.This piece originally aired August 14, 2025.Related episodes:The celebrity crypto nexusThe Olympian to influencer pipeline (Apple/Spotify)For sponsor-free episodes of The Indicator from Planet Money, subscribe to Planet Money+ via Apple Podcasts or atplus.npr.org.Fact-checking bySierra Juarez. stories.headline: Cautious homeowner receives advice about snagging disappearing federal incentives for HVACs: 'Should I pull the trigger now?'
stories.summary: Since news was released about federal tax incentives being eliminated for energy-saving home upgrades, there has been a flurry of activity aroundheat pumps. Many homeowners have recently updated their homes' outdated heating and cooling systems with this efficient technology.

stories.headline: 2 teens arrested in connection to deadly supermarket shooting on White Ln
stories.summary: BAKERSFIELD, Calif. (KGET) — Two 17-year-old boys were arrested in connection to an alleged robbery and shooting at a Bakersfield Foods Co. store on Friday night that left a victim who tried to intervene dead, officials said.

stories.headline: US capture of Maduro divides a changed region, thrilling Trump's allies and threatening his foes
stories.summary: MEXICO CITY (AP) — In his celebratory news conference onthe U.S. capture of Venezuelan strongmanleader Nicolás Maduro,President Donald Trumpset out an extraordinarily forthright view of the use of U.S. power in Latin America that exposed political divisions from Mexico to Argentina asTrump-friendly leaders riseacross the region.

stories.headline: Elon Musk dined with Donald Trump during a very busy weekend for the president
stories.summary: Elon Musk had dinner with Donald Trump amid a packed weekend for the president.

stories.headline: Trump warns of higher tariffs on India over Russian oil purchases
stories.summary: NEW DELHI, Jan 5 (Reuters) - The United States could raise tariffs on India if New Delhi doesn't meet Washington's demand ​to curb purchases of Russian oil, President Donald Trump told ‌reporters aboard Air Force One.

stories.headline: Slain Minnesota lawmaker's children call on Trump to remove social media video amplifying false claims about her death
stories.summary: The children of slain Minnesota state lawmaker Melissa Hortman are urging President Donald Trump to remove a post on Truth Social that promotes a conspiracy theory alleging the state's governor, Tim Walz, was involved in Hortman’s death.

stories.headline: Trump says that Ukraine didn't target Putin residence in a drone strike as Kremlin claims
stories.summary: ABOARD AIR FORCE ONE (AP) — President Donald Trump on Sunday told reporters that U.S. officials have determined that Ukraine did not target a residence belonging to Russian PresidentVladimir Putinin a drone attack last week,disputing Kremlin claimsthat Trump had initially greeted with deep concern.

stories.headline: Jeffries Gives Trump Brutal Reality Check About Claims That He’s Going To ‘Run’ Venezuela
stories.summary: House Minority LeaderHakeem Jeffrieshammered President Donald Trump’s claims that he will “run” Venezuela after having attacked the country and″captured” its leader.

stories.headline: Accessibility Statement
stories.summary: HuffPost values audience diversity and inclusion, and to that end, we are actively working to further enhance the accessibility of our websites to visitors who use digital assistive technologies like screen readers, screen magnifiers, or voice recognition software. We view accessibility as an ongoing effort.
